title: The impact of the early environment on oxytocin receptor epigenetics and potential therapeutic implications
affiliations: Department of Neurology, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, USA
Department of Pediatrics, Division of Neonatology, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, USA
background: Oxytocin research is rapidly evolving and increasingly reveals that epigenetic modifications to the oxytocin receptor gene (OXTR) are functional, plastic, and reliable components of oxytocinergic system function.
hypotheses: Early life experiences shape OXTR epigenetics and impact social-developmental outcomes.
OXTR methylation serves as a predictive mechanism for neurodevelopmental outcomes.
OXTRm may impact additional cellular mechanisms with therapeutic potential.
Early life therapies may target the tuning of endogenous OXTRm.
major_findings: Early life environment significantly impacts OXTR DNA methylation (OXTRm) in both animal models and humans.
OXTRm serves as a predictive biomarker for neurodevelopmental outcomes, including social behavior and psychopathology.
Specific CpG sites within the OXTR gene show a strong association between methylation levels and gene expression.
OXTRm is a potential therapeutic target for improving oxytocin therapeutics and addressing neurodevelopmental disorders.
